Fig. 9 Unraveling the mechanism of ethane oxidative dehydrogenation and the important role of CO2 over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts Huahua Fan Writing – original draft Visualization Validation Methodology Formal analysis a 1 Xiaowa Nie Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ 1 Chunshan Song Writing – review & editing Validation a b Xinwen Guo Validation Supervision Project administration Investigation Funding acquisition a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Frontier Science Center for Smart Materials, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Frontier Science Center for Smart Materials, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 China State Key Laboratory of Fine Chemicals, Frontier Science Center for Smart Materials, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China b Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, NT, Hong Kong, China Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, The Chinese University of Hong Kong Shatin NT Hong Kong, China Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, NT, Hong Kong, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work This work studies the reaction mechanism and the role of CO2 in ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over two types of Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts. The calculation results demonstrate that the Pt-Zn sites have different roles, and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is more active than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 due to more efficient Pt-Zn sites for dehydrogenation with the assistance of framework O of ZSM-5. CO2 reacts with H- species generated from ethane dehydrogenation and creates new and facile H-consuming routes, thus promoting the reaction. The positive effect of CO2 is more significant over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 owing to the largely reduced barrier of rate-limiting step. Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 greatly suppresses the competitive side reaction of CO2 with ethyl species, thus becoming a promising catalyst for ethene generation. This work deepens the mechanistic understanding of CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of light alkanes over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts and unravels the important role of CO2, providing a useful reference for future catalyst design. Graphical Abstract Keywords Ethane dehydrogenation Role of CO2 Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 Active sites Reaction mechanism Density functional theory Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethene is a central basic feedstock for the petrochemical industry, and is an important index to assess a national petrochemical industry. It is widely used in the manufacture of agriculture, construction, medicine, dyes, automobiles, and daily chemicals. Steam cracking of liquid hydrocarbons (such as petroleum oil) is the conventional process of producing ethene in industry, which requires a high reaction temperature (usually above 1073 K) and is environmentally unfriendly. What’s worse, the reactant conversion and ethene selectivity of steam cracking reactions are always unsatisfactory. It has been detected that there is a huge reserve of shale gas in the globe, which influences the current energy landscape of the world. With the consideration of sustainable strategy and the development of shale gas exploitation technology, the utilization of energy could be shifted from petroleum and coal to shale gas. Ethane is the second component (3 ∼ 16 vol %) of shale gas after methane [1], and the boom of shale gas has led to an increase in ethane production and a fall of its market price. Therefore, the production of ethene from the dehydrogenation of adequate and low-cost ethane is a promising route along with the current sustainable development trend. At present, the non-oxidative direct dehydrogenation (DDH), O2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation (O2-ODH), and CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation (CO2-ODH) are three main routes for ethene production from ethane. The DDH of ethane is a highly endothermic reaction, which proceeds at a high temperature and suffers from catalyst deactivation due to the carbon deposition [2]. The O2-ODH of ethane is an exothermic reaction, proceeding at a lower temperature, however, the strong oxidizability of O2 leads to a deep oxidization of ethane and converts the target ethene product to carbon oxides (COx), inevitably decreasing the selectivity of ethene [3]. As a soft oxidant, the greenhouse gas CO2 can be used to assist the dehydrogenation of ethane, in which the deep oxidation reactions can be effectively suppressed while the reverse Boudouard reaction of CO2 can consume the carbon deposits, thus prolonging the life of catalysts. Moreover, according to the study of Chen’s group [4], the CO2-ODH of ethane is a potential reaction to achieve negative CO2 emissions. The CO2-ODH reaction not only converts abundant and inexpensive ethane into more valuable chemical feedstock ethene, but also alleviates the environmental pressure caused by the continuously growing CO2 concentration, which is of great significance for energy conservation and emission reduction. In the literature, it has been reported that the catalyst supports employed in CO2-ODH reaction are mainly composed of metal oxides (e.g. SiO2, TiO2, CeO2, and Al2O3) and zeolites (e.g. ZSM-5, TS-1, MCM-41, and SSZ-13) [5–17]. Zeolite catalysts possess tunable acidity and good hydrothermal stability. In addition, the unique pore environment of zeolites can absorb and activate CO2 effectively to better assist the dehydrogenation of ethane reactants [6]. The specific pore structure and tunable acidic properties of zeolites can diversify the products in CO2-ODH of ethane from yielding CO and ethene to other high-value chemical products such as aromatic hydrocarbons via a tandem reaction system [18,19]. Metals such as Cr, Zn, Fe, Pt, and Ga have been reported as promising active components for the modification of zeolite catalysts in order to achieve better catalytic performance [6–8,20–22]. As a noble metal, Pt-based catalysts have been commonly used in the dehydrogenation of light alkanes with a high dehydrogenation rate but suffer from low selectivity and durability [23–31]. The addition of a second metal component such as Zn can improve the distribution of Pt and reduce its particle size, suppressing the catalyst sintering and side reactions such as the cracking of alkanes [32]. Furthermore, the electron density of Pt can be adjusted by the addition of a second metal component, thus being able to regulate the selectivity of alkenes and decrease the coke formation to prolong catalyst life [33,34]. Bian et al. [35] reported that the presence of CO2 can effectively eliminate Fe(0) active sites for side reactions to inhibit the formation of coke rather than consuming the coke via reverse Boudouard reaction in CO2-ODH of propane over bimetallic Pt-Fe/silicalite-1 catalyst. Rodaum et al. [36] investigated the CO2-ODH of propane over Pt-Zn/silicalite-1, and concluded that the synergistic effect of bimetallic Pt-Zn shifts the reaction equilibrium towards propene generation by H2 consumption via the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, and weakens the CO-metal surface interactions, alleviating the catalysts deactivation resultant from the CO poisoning, thus prolonging the catalytic lifetime and achieving an outstanding catalytic performance. Zn is a cheap metal that can be used as an active component in dehydrogenation reactions. Besides regulating the electronic properties of Pt catalyst, Zn also can catalyze the CO2-ODH reaction of light alkanes by itself. For example, Liu et al. [37] obtained high ethane conversion and ethene yield in the CO2-ODH reaction of ethane over Zn/ZSM-5, and elucidated the reaction networks of CO2-ODH in which CO2 participates in the ODH reaction via an indirect way and shifts the reaction equilibrium by reacting with H2 generated from dehydrogenation to form CO and H2O, leading to an enhanced ethene selectivity. At present, most mechanistic studies on the catalytic dehydrogenation of light alkanes over Pt-Zn catalysts used bimetallic alloy surfaces as computational models, but the function of zeolite support was usually ignored. The pore structure and particular features of zeolite such as acidity may play a role in impacting the catalytic activity, product selectivity, and catalyst stability in CO2-ODH of light alkanes, which should be taken into account. Qi et al. [38] successfully developed novel Pt-Zn complexes based on the Si-OH nests of zeolite catalysts, which show superior catalytic performance for the propane dehydrogenation reaction. The framework of zeolite plays an important role in anchoring the Pt-Zn assembles, which directly influences the catalytic performance. Therefore, the surface alloy models are unsatisfied to study the reaction mechanism for metal/zeolite systems and more reliable computational models for bimetallic Pt-Zn catalysts containing support are indispensable to understand the real active sites and catalytic mechanism for CO2-ODH of light alkanes over metal/zeolite catalysts, which will provide a useful reference for future catalyst design. In the present work, DFT calculations are performed to explore the mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene and the role of CO2 over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5. Based on the two catalyst models proposed by recent experimental studies in the literature [25,38], the reaction pathways of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalysts are identified. Pt site mainly catalyzes dehydrogenation and Zn site plays an assistant role as the acceptor of H- species bound to Pt in ethane dehydrogenation over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. In comparison, both Pt and Zn sites of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 are able to catalyze ethane dehydrogenation with the assistance of framework O of ZSM-5, which is catalytically more active than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 due to a lower barrier of the rate-limiting step. In the presence of CO2, the H- species is originated from ethane dehydrogenation which is a precursor of the rate-limiting step (H2 generation reaction) over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. Then, the formed H- species is consumed by CO2 to generate HCOOH over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 or CO+H2O over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, which simultaneously alters the rate-limiting step of ethane dehydrogenation with a decreased barrier. The RWGS reaction of CO2 reduces H2 concentration via the stepwise mechanism and promotes ethene formation from ethane dehydrogenation. From the perspective of structural and electronic property analysis, the presence of CO2 shortens the space distance required for H- species transfer in the reaction and makes the reactant states more stabilized due to the strengthened interaction between catalyst and reactant species, therefore, the energy barrier required for the reaction is reduced, making the reaction more likely to occur over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5. The Pt atoms within the active sites play an important role in stabilizing the reactant states by chemical bonding interactions over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5; in addition, the framework O site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 also has an impact on stabilizing the reactant species through charge transfer. The calculation results reveal that Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is a more promising catalyst than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 for the CO2-assisted ethane dehydrogenation to ethene, which can suppress the carbon utilization side reaction competed with the generation of target ethene product, benefiting the selectivity of ethene. It is worth mentioning that the competitive adsorption of CO2 with ethane has a negative effect on ethane conversion and is necessary to take measures to minimize it, for example, regulating and controlling the interaction forms between active metals and support, as well as the interaction forms within the active metals themselves. 2 Computational details 2.1 Computational methods All periodic DFT calculations in this work were performed by using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP). The projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials were applied to describe the interactions between ion cores and electrons [39–41]. The exchange and correlation energies were considered using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) method with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh of (PBE) functional [42]. The dispersion interaction of the zeolite-involved system was treated by the PBE+D3 method [43,44]. The cutoff energy of the plane-wave basis set was set to 400 eV and the convergence criterion of structural optimization was the forces less than 0.05 eV/Å on all atoms. The Brillouin zone was restricted by Gamma-point and all atoms included in calculations were fully optimized. Transition states (denoted as TS) were searched by using the climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [45]. Vibration frequency calculations were carried out to ensure the transition state with a single imaginary frequency along the reaction coordinate. The adsorption energy, reaction energy, and activation barrier are important energy parameters to be calculated in this work, which are denoted as E ads, E rxn, and E act, respectively. E ads is obtained from the energy difference between the catalyst with adsorbed species and the total energy of bare catalyst and adsorbate in the gas phase. E rxn is obtained from the energy difference between the reactant state and product state corresponding to the given elementary reaction. E act is obtained from the energy difference between the reactant state and transition state corresponding to each elementary reaction. Electronic structural calculations were performed to explore the intrinsic nature of catalytic reactions and acquire a deeper understanding of the energy pathway and reaction mechanism. The charge transfer properties between catalyst and adsorbates were analyzed by Bader charge calculations using the code developed by the Hekelman’s group [46]. The Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) analysis utilizes the electronic wave function to provide detailed molecular orbital information, quantifying the bonding/antibonding orbital overlap and bond strength. In this work, the chemical bond interactions of atoms participated in the reaction were evaluated by the COHP analysis. 2.2 Construction and analysis of computational models In this work, two latest reported and advanced Pt-Zn bimetal catalysts were constructed to mimic different Pt-Zn interactions within the ZSM-5 zeolite according to recent experimental studies in the literature, which are classified as subnanometer Pt-Zn bimetal cluster and hydroxyl-anchored Pt-Zn bimetal confined in the ZSM-5 pore. Subnanometer bimetallic clusters are great potential substitutes for nanoparticulate catalysts, which possess more accessible active sites and improved activity for light alkanes conversion. And the confinement effect of zeolite can suppress the aggregation of subnanometer metal clusters thus enhancing the catalyst stability. According to the recent studies on subnanometer Pt-based (Pt metal or Pt-M bimetal) catalysts [25,47,48], the active cluster is rifely in the form of a triangular pyramidal structure with 4 atoms, which delivers superior catalytic activity and stability. More specifically, the Pt-Zn subnanometer cluster consisting of three Pt atoms and a Zn atom was synthesized via a ligand-protected direct hydrogen reduction method developed by Sun et al. [25] and the cluster was encaged in the intersectional position between the straight and sinusoidal 10MR channels of the MFI topological framework of silicalite-1 (S-1) zeolite. The synthesized subnanometer Pt–Zn/S-1 zeolite catalyst was prevented from sintering and had super high propene selectivity (99.3 %) and low deactivation in the propane dehydrogenation reaction. Pt metal in the subnanometer cluster had higher surface electron density, which facilitated the desorption of olefin product and suppressed the polymerization of unsaturated coke, thereof improving the propene selectivity and catalyst stability. Therefore, in this work, it is reasonable to construct the Pt3Zn1 cluster model with the form of a triangular pyramidal structure as the optimal active structure of tiny Pt-Zn bimetallic entities confined in the MFI-type zeolite and placed it in the intersectional position between the straight and sinusoidal 10MR channels. Constructing hydroxyl defects to anchor active metals is another popular and effective strategy to enhance the reaction performance and improve the stability of catalysts. Based on this concept, anchoring noble metals by non-noble-metal nests can maximize the utilization of noble metal and prevent metal sintering. According to relevant studies in the literature [38,49,50], the (Si-O-Metal)4–6(nobel-Metal) has been proposed as the active species. For example, atomically dispersed Pt in a small nest of nonprecious Zn metal ((Si-O-Zn)4–6Pt complex) catalyst has been reported by Qi et al. [38]. They used hydroxyl nests of Beta zeolite skeleton to stabilize Zn, then the formed Zn-OH anchored Pt atom. Both Zn and Pt components were reduced after the pretreatment and finally formed an atomically dispersed isolated Pt active site with the maximum utilization of noble metal, which exhibited high activity and selectivity in the propane dehydrogenation reaction. In this catalyst, the zeolite framework contributed to dispersing and confining the bimetal complexes by creating silanol nests, which also provided the polarized O active sites to participate in the dehydrogenation reaction [51]. In a later study, analogous Pt1-Znn (n=4–6) bimetal active complexes confined into the ZSM-5 zeolite were obtained by Chen et al. [52], similar to the above synthesis strategy. In the process of constructing the computational model in this work, it was found that in the pore environment of zeolite, only when the value of n of Pt1-Znn (n=4–6) species was set to 6, the Pt atom can be well dispersed and confined in the Zn-nests without being attracted away to the framework O of zeolite. Therefore, it is reasonable to construct (Si-O-Zn)6Pt1 as the active species for further investigation. Based on the structural information of active metals in zeolite pores and characterization results containing the local coordination number and bond length information corresponding to the aforementioned two catalysts reported in the experimental studies in the literature [25,38], the computational models of Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 in this work were constructed and denoted as Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 representing different Pt-Zn interactions. The optimized structures of these two catalysts are shown in Fig. 1. Bader charge and differential charge density calculations were performed to analyze the two catalyst models. The metal species transfers charge of 7.72δ- to the zeolite substrate in the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 model, while the charge transferred from the metal species to the zeolite substrate in Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 is very small, only 0.02δ-. Compared to Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, obviously, the zeolite substrate has a more significant effect on the active metal species in the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 model. In combination with the differential charge density profile shown in Figure S1A, it can be seen that a large proportion of positive or negative electron density regions (solid black circle in Figure S1A) mainly appears within the metal cluster while minor (dashed black circle in Figure S1A ) appears between the metal cluster and zeolite substrate over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. This suggests that the electron transfer occurs primarily within the metal cluster rather than with the zeolite substrate over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. The results of Bader charge indicate that Pt atoms of Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 mainly gain electrons (charge of − 0.24 for each Pt atom) while the Zn atom loses electrons (charge of +0.73); and the total numbers of electrons gained and lost within the Pt3Zn1 cluster are approximately equal, consistent with the calculation result of differential charge density shown in Figure S1A. Both the experimental and our computational results show that Pt metals in the Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 subnanometer cluster are electron enriched [25]. For the trace electron exchange between the zeolite substrate and Pt3Zn1 metal cluster (0.02δ-), it is found that the O atoms far away from the metal cluster gain charge of − 1.95 ∼ − 2.10, while that is − 1.96 ∼ − 1.99 for O atoms nearby the Pt3Zn1 cluster, thus the quantity of exchanged charge is very small, leading to a slight effect of zeolite framework on the electron distribution of Pt3Zn1 subnanometer cluster. The above results indicate that the zeolite skeleton in Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 mainly plays a role in confining the Pt-Zn bimetal cluster, and has a slight effect on the electronic regulation of Pt-Zn bimetallic particles. With regard to the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst, there are larger electron density regions between the Zn6Pt1 portion and the surrounding framework O atoms of ZSM-5, as shown in Figure S1B. For Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, both Pt and Zn metals lose electrons (charge of +0.24 for Pt atom, and +1.25 for each Zn atom), consistent with the experimental results showing that Pt atom is slight positively charged and nearly zero valent state while Zn is in an oxidation state approximately to +1 valence [38]. According to the studies of light alkanes dehydrogenation over metal-modified zeolites [51,53,54], the O atom bridging the modified metal atom and the framework Si atom (namely, the O of M-O-Si unit) is polarized and constitutes the Mδ+-Oδ- pair with modified metal to participate in catalyzing light alkanes conversion, in which the Oδ- site plays a role in accepting/releasing H species from light alkanes in the dehydrogenation process. Meanwhile, our calculation results show that the O atoms acted as bridging sites to combine skeleton Si and the Zn6Pt1 complex have gained charge of − 1.56 ∼ − 1.70, obviously less than that of O atoms far away from the Zn6Pt1 cluster (− 1.97 ∼ − 2.08). Thus, it can be inferred that the polarized O sites of zeolite generated on the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst would participate in the dehydrogenation of ethane. In general, for the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst, the zeolite skeleton not only confines the Pt-Zn bimetal complex, but also regulates the electronic distribution of metal sites by charge transfer, and provides additional active polarized O sites for ethane dehydrogenation reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts 3.1.1 Reaction pathways identified over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 The adsorption of ethane over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 is first examined (Figure S2a) and the adsorption energy of the most stable adsorption configuration is calculated to be − 0.88 eV. With the adsorption of ethane over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, the methyl group of ethane close to the Pt site has more obvious electron transfer with the active metal site as observed in Figure S3 (black circle). Bader charge calculation results show that the ethane transfers charge of 0.06 δ- to Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, indicating ethane is partially activated upon its adsorption on the Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 catalyst. The subsequent dehydrogenation may proceed through three pathways, which are single Pt site catalysis, synergistic Pt-Pt site catalysis, and synergistic Pt-Zn site catalysis. The reaction energy and activation barrier are used as key energy parameters to screen the optimal pathway for ethane dehydrogenation over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. As shown in Figure S4, single Pt is the most active site to catalyze the C-H bond cleavage of ethane to generate the C2H5- intermediate with the lowest activation barrier (0.09 eV) and most favorable reaction energy (-0.47 eV) compared to the energy parameters calculated for other catalytic sites. In this dehydrogenation process, the generated C2H5- and H- species are bonded to the same Pt site (Figure S2b). To proceed with further dehydrogenation of C2H5-, the H bound to the original Pt site needs to migrate to other metal sites (such as Zn and Pt) of the Pt3Zn1 cluster to release the proximate active site and reaction space. The structure obtained by the transfer of H to Zn site is energetically more stable than that transferred to the other Pt site with an energy difference of 0.15 eV. In addition, it is found that the generated species from further dehydrogenation corresponding to the H…Zn migration is also energetically more stable than that corresponding to the H…Pt migration, with an energy difference of 0.34 eV. These calculation results indicate that Zn is a more suitable H acceptor than Pt in the Pt3Zn1 cluster and a synergistic action of Pt-Zn sites for the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene is identified. Therefore, after the first dehydrogenation step of ethane, the abstracted H atom bonded to Pt preferentially transfers to Zn of the Pt3Zn1 cluster (Figure S2c), followed by further β-H abstraction of C2H5- forming adsorbed C2H4 with a barrier of 0.79 eV, and the abstracted β-H is adsorbed at the original Pt site (Figure S2d). In the process of ethene formation, two H atoms are dispersing on the Pt3Zn1 cluster as an H2 generation precursor, and they can be co-adsorbed in three ways. As shown in Figure S5A, the two H atoms co-adsorbed over a single Pt site is the energetically most stable structure (Figure S2e), while those co-adsorbed over a synergistic Pt-Zn site are only 0.06 eV less stable; the two H atoms co-adsorbed on the Pt-Pt dual site is 0.40 eV less stable than adsorbing on the single Pt site simultaneously. In addition, the migration of H atoms on the metal sites of Pt3Zn1 was examined and the obtained energy diagram is shown in Figure S5B. It is found that the change of adsorption sites of the two H atoms by migration can proceed with a maximum barrier of 0.96 eV, thus the H migration on the Pt3Zn1 cluster is possible to occur. Finally, the two H atoms co-adsorbed on the single Pt site combine with each other and generate an H2 molecule (Figure S2f), which then desorbs from the active metal site. The optimal energy diagram for ethane dehydrogenation to ethene is mapped out in Fig. 2, and the corresponding Gibbs free energy diagram calculated at 873 K is provided in Figure S6. The optimized structures of all states involved are provided in Figure S2. The calculation results reveal that ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 proceeds by the synergistic catalysis of Pt-Zn active sites with the final H2 generation as the rate-limiting step (barrier of 1.64 eV). 3.1.2 Reaction pathways identified over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 The adsorption ability of Pt and Zn sites in Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 toward the ethane molecule is investigated and the adsorption energy of the most stable configuration (Figure S7A -a and Figure S7B -a) is calculated to be −0.70 eV on the Pt site and −0.48 eV on the Zn site. The electron transfer between ethane and the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst is tiny, which is 0.03 δ- on the Pt site and 0.01 δ- on the Zn site. All C-H bond distances of the adsorbed ethane remain ∼1.10 Å, which is almost equal to that of the gaseous ethane molecule. Therefore, it can be inferred that ethane is weakly adsorbed over the active metal sites of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, with the Pt site adsorption stronger than the Zn site. For the dehydrogenation of ethane over the Pt active site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, the first H atom abstracted from ethane could be accepted not only by the skeleton O of zeolite but also by the Pt site together with C2H5-. All structures involved in this process are shown in Figure S7A. For the former path that H transferred to skeleton O, the structure of C2H5- and O-H generated from the first H abstraction of ethane is relatively stable (Figure S7A -b R1 ), and the dehydrogenation reaction is exothermic by releasing the energy of 1.86 eV without a barrier (R1-Step1). In the next step, the β-H of C2H5- needs to transfer to the Pt site to generate ethene and Pt-H species (Figure S7A -c R1 ), which needs to overcome a barrier of 1.04 eV (R1-Step2). The final H2 generation from the Pt-H and O-H species (Figure S7A -d) is the rate-limiting step with a barrier of 1.50 eV (R1-Step3). For the other path that H transferred to the Pt site (Figure S7A -b R2 ), the two H atoms of ethane are successively dehydrogenated to the Pt active site associated with the generation of ethene and H-Pt-H (Figure S7A -c R2 ), which needs to surmount barriers of 0.56 eV (R2-Step1) and 1.71 eV (R2-Step2), respectively. Finally, H2 generation from H-Pt-H (Figure S7A -d) needs to overcome a small barrier of 0.27 eV (R2-Step3). In this path, the β-H abstraction from C2H5- is the rate-limiting step with a high barrier of 1.71 eV. As shown in Figure S8, comparing the two pathways for ethane dehydrogenation over the Pt active site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, the synergistic dehydrogenation action between Pt and skeleton O is the optimal pathway than that catalyzed by solely the Pt site (rate-limiting barrier of 1.50 vs. 1.71 eV). The optimal energy pathway of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over the Pt active site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is illustrated in Fig. 3 (blue line), with the corresponding Gibbs free energy diagram calculated at 873 K plotted in Figure S9 (blue line). As a contrast, the dehydrogenation performance over the Zn active site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is also investigated, with all structures involved provided in Figure S7B. According to the reported reaction mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation over Zn/ZSM-5 in the literature [55], over the Zn active site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, the first H of ethane dehydrogenates to the oxygen atom near Zn site with the generation of C2H5- and O-H species (R1-Step1, Figure S7B -b), which needs to overcome a barrier of 1.54 eV. The formed C2H5- species further gets rid of the β-H to the Zn site to generate ethene, Zn-H, and O-H species (R1-Step2, Figure S7B -c R1 ) with a barrier of 1.80 eV. As the precursor of H2 generation, the formed Zn-H subsequently reacts with the O-H species to generate H2 (R1-Step3, Figure S7B -d R1 ), with a barrier of 1.34 eV. In another alternative route, the formed C2H5- directly reacts with the O-H species to generate ethene and H2 (Figure S7B -c R2 ) rather than prior dehydrogenation to the Zn site, which needs to surmount a barrier of 1.40 eV (denoted as R2-Step2). Compared to R1-Step2 and R1-Step3, the reaction of C2H5- with O-H that directly generating H2 and ethene (R2-Step2) is the dominant route due to a relatively lower barrier (1.40 vs. 1.80 and 1.34 eV, Figure S8). The optimal reaction pathway for ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is illustrated in Fig. 3 (black line), and the rate-limiting step is the dehydrogenation of ethane to form C2H5- species (barrier of 1.54 eV). The corresponding Gibbs free energy diagram calculated at 873 K is provided in Figure S9 (black line). In our previous work,[55] an optimal route for ethane dehydrogenation to ethene was identified over the (Zn-O-Zn)2+ active site of Zn/ZSM-5, which went through C2H6→C2H5- (R1-Step1), C2H5-→C2H4+Zn-H+O-H (R1-Step2), and Zn-H+O-H→H2 (R1-Step3), as shown in Figure S8. Over the Zn site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, the barriers of corresponding R1-Step1 and R1-Step3 are increased by 0.73 and 0.21 eV, respectively, compared to that occurred over the (Zn-O-Zn)2+ active site of Zn/ZSM-5. Especially, the barrier of R1-Step1 increases considerably, indicating that the initial activation of ethane C-H bond becomes more difficult over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 than Zn/ZSM-5. However, through the optimal energy pathway over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, the barrier of (R2-Step2) (C2H5-→C2H4+H2) decreases to 1.40 eV over the Zn active site, which hardly proceeds over the (Zn-O-Zn)2+ site of Zn/ZSM-5 with a high barrier of 2.23 eV (Figure S8), thus the direct reaction of C2H5- with O-H to generate C2H4 and H2 could not occur over Zn/ZSM-5, leading to different pathways. Compared to (Zn-O-Zn)2+ catalyzed ethane dehydrogenation over Zn/ZSM-5, the rate-limiting step moves forward, from β-H abstraction over Zn/ZSM-5 to ethane first C-H bond activation over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, and the rate-limiting barrier is decreased by 0.29 eV (Figure S8), indicating that the dehydrogenation of ethane is promoted over the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst. Based on the calculation results above, the role of metal active site in the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is systematically discussed. For the reaction occurred over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, it reveals that the Pt site is mainly responsible for the dehydrogenation of ethane, while the Zn site acts as an acceptor of H bound to Pt, which is beneficial to the reduction of the energy barrier and the release of reaction space for subsequent catalytic dehydrogenation over the Pt active site. Therefore, the Zn site plays an assistant role for Pt in ethane dehydrogenation over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. For the reaction occurred over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, both Zn and Pt sites are catalytically active for ethane dehydrogenation with the participation of framework O of ZSM-5 by accepting/releasing the H species from ethane dehydrogenation. At 0 K and 873 K, the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst both has the lowest barrier (1.50 eV at 0 K and 1.34 at 873 K) of the rate-limiting step of the optimal pathways among all active sites over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, thus the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst is more active for the ethane dehydrogenation to ethene. The reaction rate constants (k cat) calculated based on Gibbs free energies at the reaction temperature of 873 K are provided in Table S1, which confirm that the rate-limiting steps of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over the two catalysts do not change and the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 remains the best catalytic performance towards ethane dehydrogenation at the reaction temperature of 873 K. As illustrated in Table S2, the dynamic charge evolvement of framework O involved in the reaction evidences that the O site can also act as an electron reservoir to regulate the charge distribution in the whole catalytic process, thus assisting the ethane dehydrogenation over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. In comparison to the (Zn-O-Zn)2+ site catalysis over Zn/ZSM-5, the barrier of rate-limiting step of ethane dehydrogenation over the Zn active site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is also lower (1.54 vs.1.83 eV). These calculation results indicate that the addition of Pt component is very important to promote ethane hydrogenation over the Zn/ZSM-5 catalyst. Meanwhile, the structure, size and bimetallic interaction of Pt-Zn assembly in the Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalyst play an essential role in dictating the catalytic activity and reaction pathway for ethane dehydrogenation, and the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 outperforms due to more efficient catalytic sites of both Pt and Zn, especially for the Pt sites with the assistant of framework O of ZSM-5. Our calculation results are consistent with the relevant experimental results on the dehydrogenation of light alkanes in the literature [25,38], which show that for the reaction of propane dehydrogenation to propene (PDH) at 823 K, the 0.04Pt-0.36ZnDeAlBEA catalyst with (Si-O-Zn)4–6Pt active complex has a higher apparent rate coefficient than the PtZn@S-1 catalyst with Pt3Zn1 active subnanometer cluster; moreover, compared to PtZn@S-1, the 04Pt-0.36ZnDeAlBEA catalyst shows a lower deactivation factor and a higher propene selectivity, as demonstrated in Table S3. Therefore, the Pt-Zn bimetal catalyst with Zn6Pt1 active species exhibits a higher activity than that with Pt3Zn1 active species. 3.2 The effects of CO2 on ethane dehydrogenation over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts The effects of CO2 on the alkane dehydrogenation as well as the subsequent aromatization reaction of alkene over metal-modified ZSM-5 have been reported in the literature [18,19,37,56]. On the one hand, CO2 may react with the intermediate species such as the alkyl group or M-H species, resulting in a positive or negative effect on the corresponding elementary step in the process of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene. On the other hand, CO2 can react with the generated H2 via the RWGS reaction, moving the equilibrium toward generation of more alkenes. Besides, other advantageous influences of CO2 have been reported, such as the restraint of loss of active metallic Zn and the improvement of catalyst stability by consuming carbon deposits [57]. In this work, we focused on examining the reactions of CO2 with M-H species (M=Pt and O), ethyl intermediate, and H2 species to uncover the role of CO2 via participating in the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts. 3.2.1 The competitive adsorption for CO2, ethane, and ethene molecules For CO2-assisted oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes, the competitive adsorption of CO2 with reactants and products is an inevitable problem that needs to be alleviated. Therefore, the adsorptions of ethane, ethene, and CO2 over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 are first studied (Figure S10). Considering the high catalytic activity of coordination unsaturated Pt atoms in metal clusters, the monometallic Pt4 cluster is chosen as a contrast catalyst to discuss [58]. As shown in Table S4, the adsorption of CO2 and ethane is weak, while the adsorption of ethene is strong over the monometallic Pt4 cluster [59,60]. With the introduction of Zn metal, the adsorption energy of CO2 and ethane is increased over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5, benefiting the adsorption and activation of CO2 and ethane reactants. The adsorption energy of ethene is significantly decreased over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 (Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5) comparing to that on the monometallic Pt4 cluster, thus facilitating the ethene desorption and improving the selectivity of ethene product over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 (Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5). This effect is attributed to the addition of Zn metal tuning the electronic feature of Pt [33,34]. It is noted that the competitive adsorption of CO2 with ethane still affects the conversion of ethane, which can be considered as one crucial aspect in future catalyst design for CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of alkanes over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 and needs to take measures to alleviate. The adsorption energy difference between ethane and CO2 over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 (0.67 eV) and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 (0.44 eV) indicates that the interaction forms between active metals and zeolite support, as well as the interaction forms within the active metals themselves affect the degree of competitive adsorption between CO2 and ethane, thus regulation of the interaction between each component would be an approach to alleviate the negative competitive adsorption. Compared to monometallic Zn/ZSM-5 catalyst [55,61], the Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalyst has higher adsorption and activation ability for CO2, thus is beneficial for the CO2-ODH reaction. 3.2.2 The effect of CO2 on the rate-limiting reaction of ethane dehydrogenation As discussed above, the rate-limiting steps of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene in the optimal energy pathway over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 are the H-Pt-H→H2 (Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5), Pt-H+O-H→H2 (Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5), and C2H6→C2H5- + O-H (Zn site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5), which need to overcome barriers of 1.64, 1.50, and 1.54 eV, respectively. In the presence of CO2, it can react with the reactant species of the rate-limiting step, thus inducing a new reaction route with an increased or decreased barrier, that is to say, CO2 may have a positive or negative effect on these rate-limiting steps. Therefore, the reactions between CO2 and the reactant states (H-Pt-H over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, Pt-H+O-H over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 and C2H6 over the Zn site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5) are calculated to evaluate the effect of CO2 on the rate-limiting steps of ethane dehydrogenation. The most stable adsorbed H- species (H-Pt-H) is chosen to investigate the reaction with CO2 to uncover the influence of CO2 on the activation barrier of rate-limiting step in ethane dehydrogenation over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. With the adsorption of CO2 over the Pt active site of Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, CO2 becomes bent from the linear structure of CO2 gas, and the C-O bond length increases to 1.21–1.28 from 1.18 Å, indicating the activation of CO2 upon adsorption. Whereafter, the H- adsorbed on the Pt site of Pt3Zn1 transfers to the C atom (denoted as H-C reaction) or O atom (denoted as H-O reaction) of CO2 to generate HCOO- or -COOH species, respectively. The calculation results show that the HCOO- species is easier to generate with a lower reaction energy (0.39 eV) and activation barrier (0.49 eV), while the generation of -COOH species is more difficult with a higher reaction energy (0.50 eV) and activation barrier (1.59 eV). Finally, the unsaturated O atom of HCOO- bonded to Pt accepts the other H- to generate the HCOOH species, which is the rate-limiting step in the process of H- consumption by CO2 and has a barrier of 1.32 eV. Compared with the barrier (1.64 eV) of rate-limiting step of ethane dehydrogenation without CO2, the rate-limiting barrier of the reaction between CO2 and H-Pt-H is decreased by 0.32 eV, indicating that the introduction of CO2 can react with the H-Pt-H species and avert the H2 generation reaction with high barriers, providing a new H-consuming route and facilitating the reaction. The reaction products may also contain CO and H2O, mostly generated from the subsequent dissociation of HCOOH species. The optimal reaction pathway for the reaction of CO2 with H-Pt-H in the process of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 is illustrated in Fig. 4 (black line). All the optimized structures involved are shown in Figure S11. Compared with Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, the mechanism of CO2-involved reaction over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 becomes manifold and complex, due to the diversity of reactants (Pt-H and O-H), products (HCOO- and -COOH), and active sites (Pt and polarized O sites). As discussed above, in the absence of CO2, the activation barrier of the rate-limiting step (Pt-H+O-H→H2) over the Pt active site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is calculated to be 1.50 eV. To simplify the investigation, the rate-limiting barrier of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene in the absence of CO2 is used as an index to conduct a preliminary screening for the reaction energy changed by the introduction of CO2 to identify the potential positive reactions. All reactions between CO2 and H- species are fully considered to find the stable intermediates and dominant pathway according to the barrier index value (1.50 eV). As the reaction energy diagram shown in Figure S12 (left), the generation of intermediates S3-S5 (Figure S13 (A)) is energetically favorable with lower reaction energies. For these three intermediates, the H- species of Pt-H and C atom of CO2 react to generate the intermediate S3 (H-C reaction), while that reacts with the O atom of CO2 generating the intermediate S4 and S5 (H-O reaction). The barrier of the H-C reaction to form S3 is 1.63 eV, and that of the H-O reaction to form intermediate S4 is 0.95 eV, to form intermediate S5 is 1.07 eV. The inter-conversion between intermediate S4 and S5 requires to overcome a barrier of 1.39 eV. Obviously, compared to the H-C reaction, the H-O reactions between CO2 and Pt-H have more advantages to proceed. That is, the reaction of CO2 and Pt-H tends to produce the -COOH intermediate rather than HCOO- intermediate. Then, the reaction pathway with the generated -COOH intermediate (S4 or S5) is continued to be studied and it is found that the generation of H2O and CO from O-H and Pt-COOH intermediate (S5) via C-O bond cleavage and O-H bond formation is easy to occur, which has a small barrier of 0.66 eV. In addition, the other reactions originated from the -COOH intermediate (S4 or S5) are also calculated and excluded based on high reaction energies or activation barriers, including the generation of HCOOH (barrier of 2.38 eV), the C-O bond cleavage reaction to produce -OH and CO (reaction energy of 1.53 eV), and the H-transfer reaction between skeleton O and Pt (reaction energy of 1.69 eV). Based on the above calculation results, the optimal reaction pathway between CO2 and H- species over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is the H-O reaction with the generation of O-H and Pt-COOH intermediate (S5) and then producing H2O and CO, in which the generation of O-H and Pt-COOH intermediate is the rate-limiting step with a barrier of 1.07 eV. Compared to the rate-limiting barrier (1.50 eV) of ethane dehydrogenation without CO2, the rate-limiting barrier (1.07 eV) of the reaction between CO2 and H- species is obviously decreased, indicating that the introduction of CO2 induces a new and facile H-consuming path to circumvent the difficult H2 generation reaction, thus promoting the ethene formation from ethane dehydrogenation over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. In addition, the preliminary screening of reaction energy for the reaction of C2H6 with CO2 is also conducted over the Zn site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 (Figure S13 (B)) and the reaction energy diagram is shown in Figure S12 (right). Although the reactions of C2H6 with CO2 generating intermediates S3-S5 are energetically favorable with low reaction energies, the transition state structures in these reactions are unstable and need to overcome higher barriers, inferring that the positive effect of CO2 on the rate-limiting reaction of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene does not obtain over the Zn site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. To sum up, CO2 mainly promotes the ethane dehydrogenation to ethene by creating new H-consuming route and decreasing the barrier of rate-limiting step over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. The optimal reaction path for CO2 participating in the rate-limiting step in the process of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is illustrated in Fig. 4 (blue line). All the optimized structures involved are shown in Figure S13. In the presence of CO2, the reaction pathway circumvents the most difficult reaction of H2 generation and proceeds via a new H-consuming route in the process of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, which requires a lower barrier to carry on. Meanwhile, it is worth noting that the reaction mechanism over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is completely different. Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 prefers to catalyze the reaction of CO2 and the H- species via H-C reaction and the product is HCOOH species through a HCOO intermediate with a rate-limiting barrier of 1.32 eV. Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 tends to catalyze the reaction of CO2 and the H- species via H-O reaction and the product is H2O and CO species through a COOH intermediate with a rate-limiting barrier of 1.07 eV, thus the promotional role of CO2 over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is more pronounced. As shown in Fig. 5, the barriers of rate-limiting steps for ethane dehydrogenation with the participation of CO2 decrease by 0.32 and 0.43 eV over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, respectively, indicating that there is a positive effect of CO2 on the ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5, and obviously, Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 outperforms Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 due to more largely reduced barrier. It can be concluded that CO2 promotes the dehydrogenation of ethane over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 via different reaction routes induced by different interactions between the two modified metals of Pt and Zn, resulting in synergistic effects among CO2, reactant species, and the catalyst. 3.2.3 The effect of RWGS of CO2 on the reaction of ethane dehydrogenation In the process of ethane dehydrogenation, CO2 can assist the production of ethene as a soft oxidant, which avoids the deep oxidation of products. In addition, CO2 can be also used as a scavenger to consume H2 generated from ethane dehydrogenation via the RWGS reaction (CO2 + H2 → H2O + CO), reducing the concentration of H2 and leading to the forward shift of reaction equilibrium towards generating more ethene from ethane dehydrogenation. Besides, the decrease in H2 concentration can also suppress the loss of active metal component, which is beneficial for ethane dehydrogenation. Here, H2 consumption by CO2 via the RWGS reaction is mainly considered from two routes: stepwise and concerted mechanism. For the stepwise mechanism, the H2 dissociation and the reaction between H- and CO2 proceed separately. Firstly, H2 dissociates to generate the H- species adsorbed on the metal active site; then, with the adsorption of CO2, the H- species needs to leave the active site and react with CO2. Different from the stepwise mechanism, the concerted mechanism considers that the H2 dissociation proceeds simultaneously with the reaction of H- species and CO2, meaning that the H atom dissociated from H2 directly reacts with the CO2 molecule rather than being captured by the metal active site. The possible intermediates generated from the two reaction mechanisms are calculated and the reaction energies of stable intermediates are shown in Fig. 6, with the optimized structures provided in Figure S14. The stepwise and concerted mechanisms of CO2 reaction with H2 are investigated in three catalytic ways (single Pt catalysis, synergistic Pt-Pt catalysis, and synergistic Pt-Zn catalysis) over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. The first elementary step involved in all reaction routes is shown in Figure S15A (the stepwise mechanism) and S15B (the concerted mechanism) and is calculated to screen out the potentially optimal reaction pathway. The reaction energy profile is shown in Fig. 6. The calculation results of stepwise and concerted mechanisms show that all reactions are exothermic, in which the largest reaction energy of H2 dissociation in the stepwise mechanism (reaction R1) is 0.85 eV larger than that of the concerted mechanism (reaction R2), and the gap of the reaction energies between the two mechanisms is wide and considerable. Further calculation results show that the reaction R1 of the stepwise mechanism is a strongly exothermic and barrierless step. Therefore, it can be concluded that when H2 and CO2 are co-adsorbed over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, H2 is easily dissociated to produce two H- species adsorbed over the Pt metal sites (H-Pt-H) via the stepwise mechanism (reaction R1). The produced H-Pt-H species is the precursor reactant of the rate-limiting step in ethane dehydrogenation to ethene, so the subsequent reaction between H- species and CO2 can refer to the discussions in the previous Section 3.2.2. Different from the microenvironment of the active site inside Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, the two reaction mechanisms of CO2 and H2 are investigated in three manners including single Pt catalysis, Pt-O synergistic catalysis, and Zn-O synergistic catalysis over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. The first elementary steps corresponding to the two mechanisms are shown in Figure S15C (stepwise mechanism) and S15D (concerted mechanism). Similar to Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, the reactions considered in the stepwise mechanism are all exothermic, whereas in the concerted mechanism, the endothermic reaction is involved (reaction R4). As shown in Fig. 6, the lowest reaction energies of the first elementary steps corresponding to the two mechanisms are close to each other, which are reaction R2 of the stepwise mechanism (-2.21 eV) and reaction R6 of the concerted mechanism (-2.29 eV), thus the calculation results based on reaction energies cannot screen out the dominant reaction pathway. Then, the activation barriers are continually calculated and the results show that the reaction R2 of the stepwise mechanism is barrierless while a barrier of 0.20 eV is obtained for reaction R6 of the concerted mechanism. Therefore, it can be concluded that similar to Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, H2 dissociation (the stepwise mechanism, reaction R2) preferentially occurs when H2 and CO2 are co-adsorbed over the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst. Similarly, the produced Pt-H+O-H is the precursor reactant of the rate-limiting step in ethane dehydrogenation to ethene, and the subsequent reaction of Pt-H+O-H with CO2 is discussed in detail in Section 3.2.2. Comparing the most stable reaction energy of the stepwise mechanism of the first elementary step for RWGS of CO2 over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 (-1.82 vs. −2.29 eV), it reveals that the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst has a lower reaction energy, indicating a more favorable H2 dissociation occurred over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. All the optimized structures involved in these calculations are provided in Figure S14. 3.2.4 The carbon resource utilization reaction of CO2 In CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of ethane, CO2 can be used as a carbon resource to react with the generated alkyl group, and its C atom can enter into the alkene products to grow the carbon chain along with the generation of acid, ester, and other products, leading to the reduction of CO2 concentration in the atmosphere. Wei et al. [62] pointed out that the C atom of CO2 entered into the high-value aromatic products and O atoms of CO2 were ridded from the final products through the formation and removal of water in the subsequent aromatization reaction of alkane dehydrogenation assisted by CO2 over ZSM-5, so that the generation of alkenes decreased but the selectivity to aromatics improved in that process. However, the carbon utilization reaction of CO2 is a competitive side reaction for ethane dehydrogenation to ethene, which reduces the amount of olefin in the product distribution. In this section, the carbon utilization reaction of CO2 is investigated over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. Based on the literature [56,63,64], it is proposed that the O or C of CO2 reacts with the C of ethyl to generate Zeolite-C(O)O-C2H5 or Zeolite-OC(O)-C2H5 intermediate, respectively, denoted as O-C reaction and C-C reaction in this work. Compared with O-C reaction, the C-C reaction to generate the Zeolite-OC(O)-C2H5 intermediate between CO2 and C2H5- is obviously easier to proceed with a lower barrier (1.25 vs. 1.91 eV) over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, although their reaction energies have small difference (0.20 vs 0.17 eV). Subsequently, the propionic acid is generated by the reaction of H generated from C2H6 dehydrogenation and O of -OC(O)-C2H5 bonded to the Pt site, which has a reaction energy of 0.46 eV and a barrier of 1.00 eV. The above calculation results indicate that the C resource of CO2 can be utilized in the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene with the generation of propionic acid, and the rate-limiting step is the first C-C reaction with a barrier of 1.25 eV. In comparison with the rate-limiting barrier (1.32 eV) of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene assisted by CO2, clearly, the C-C reaction of CO2 with C2H5- is a competitive side reaction to occur. The optimal reaction path for the utilization of CO2 in the process of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 is plotted in Fig. 7 (black line), with all optimized structures provided in Figure S16A. The reactions of CO2 with C2H5- are also discussed from the perspective of C-C and O-C reactions over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 including both Pt and Zn active sites. The reaction energies of C-C and O-C reactions over the Pt site are − 0.10 and 0.65 eV, respectively, while those over the Zn site are − 0.77 and 0.87 eV, respectively, indicating that the C-C reaction has an obvious advantage compared to the O-C reaction no matter catalyzed by the Pt or Zn active site. Therefore, C-C reactions are continually investigated and the barrier calculation results show that the C-C reaction between CO2 and C2H5- is hard to proceed over the Pt site with a large barrier of 2.48 eV. Thus, the utilization of CO2 is an unlikely side reaction to occur over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. By contrast, the C-C reaction over the Zn active site proceeds with a lower barrier of 1.68 eV than the Pt site. The final propionic acid generation reaction from the Zeolite-OC(O)-C2H5 intermediate and O-H species over the Zn site is an exothermic reaction with a reaction energy of − 0.97 eV which is a barrierless step. These calculation results reveal that the carbon utilization of CO2 with the propionic acid generation is inclined to proceed via the C-C reaction over the Zn site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, and the rate-limiting step is the first C-C reaction with a barrier of 1.68 eV. However, compared to the rate-limiting barrier (1.50 eV) of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene in the absence of CO2 and that (1.07 eV) obtained in the presence of CO2, the C-C reaction of CO2 insertion is more difficult to occur. Therefore, this side reaction is minor over the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst. The optimal reaction path for the carbon utilization of CO2 in the process of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is plotted in Fig. 7 (blue line), with all optimized structures provided in Figure S16B and S16C. Based on the above calculation results, the influences of CO2 on the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene over the two catalysts are identified. For the Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 catalyst, CO2 assists in the dehydrogenation of ethane, but the carbon utilization of CO2 by reacting with the -C2H5 species is a serious competitive side reaction, which is not conducive to the generation of ethene product. For the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst, CO2 tends to promote the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene in different ways, such as decreasing the barrier of rate-limiting step, consuming the formed H2 via the RWGS reaction, and suppressing the side reaction of carbon utilization of CO2, which becomes a more promising candidate for ethene generation from ethane dehydrogenation. The CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of light alkanes (ethane and propane) over metal-modified zeolites has been reported in the literature. For example, over Pt-Zn/silicalite-1, CO2 can shift the reaction equilibrium of propane dehydrogenation towards propene generation by H2 consumption via the RWGS reaction; meanwhile, the synergistic effect of bimetallic Pt-Zn weakens the interactions between the generated CO and metal surface, relieving the catalyst deactivation resultant from CO poisoning, thus prolonging the catalyst life and achieving a superior catalytic performance [36]. In addition, CO2 has been reported to possess various positive effects on the catalytic dehydrogenation of light alkanes over metal-modified zeolite catalysts, including eliminating the disadvantageous active sites (Fe(0)) responsible for the coke formation over Pt-Fe/silicalite-1 and facilitating the surface hydrogen removal to avoid hydrogenolysis with the formation of CH4 over Zn/SSZ-13 [6,35,37]. Our previous experimental studies on the dehydrogenation and aromatization of light alkanes over metal-modified zeolites have also identified positive effects of CO2 in terms of catalytic activity, product selectivity, and/or catalyst stability [18,57]. Integrated from these relevant experimental literature and the calculation results on CO2 effect in this work including the reduction of barriers of rate-limiting steps, consumption of H2 via the RWGS reaction, and suppression of carbon utilization side reaction, we infer that CO2 has a positive effect on the ethane dehydrogenation over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. 3.3 Electronic properties and charge transfer analysis Based on the above calculation results, it is obvious that the decrease of rate-limiting barrier by CO2 participation most directly promotes the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene. To illuminate the intrinsic reason for this positive effect from CO2, we further analyzed the interactions between adsorbed species and catalyst including the zeolite support and active metals, according to the electronic properties and charge transfer calculations. 3.3.1 Analysis of adsorbed species With the introduction of CO2, the co-adsorption of CO2 with H- species over the active sites may have an influence on the chemical bond interaction of H- species (H-Pt-H over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Pt-H+O-H over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5), thus altering the dehydrogenation difficulty. In terms of the differential charge density profile, there are increased or depleted charge density regions between CO2 and H- species (H-Pt-H) over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, which means that the CO2-H interaction could be generated, thus inducing a strengthening or weakening on the chemical bond composited H- species ( Fig. 8A). But clearly, CO2 does not transfer charge to H- species (Pt-H+O-H) over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, indicating that CO2 adsorption does not affect the bonding interaction of H- species (Pt-H+O-H) (Fig. 8B). The impact on the strength of chemical bond composited H- species induced by CO2 is further confirmed by the COHP calculation. The results show that the integral value below the Fermi level changes a little with the adsorption of CO2 over the two catalysts, which means that there is no obvious change in the chemical bond strength of Pt-H (Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5) and Pt-H/O-H (Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5) by CO2 introduction, even if there yields the CO2-H interaction over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. The detailed COHP results are provided in Figure S17. 3.3.2 Origin of the positive effect of CO2 on the key transition state species of rate-limiting step As discussed in Section 3.2.2, after the adsorption and activation of CO2, the reactions between CO2 and H-Pt-H over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 or Pt-H+O-H over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 create new H-consuming routes that averting the formation of H2 molecules. The optimal reaction routes of CO2 with the above H-involving species over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalysts include the generation of HCOO- and -COOH, respectively, and the reaction barriers are decreased by 1.15 and 0.43 eV, respectively, comparing to the barrier of rate-limiting step (H2 generation) in the ethane dehydrogenation reaction without CO2. Therefore, after excluding the influence on the adsorbed H-involving species (H-Pt-H and Pt-H+O-H) caused by CO2, we continue to explore the transition state (TS) species from the perspective of structural and electronic effects to elucidate the intrinsic reason of the decreased barrier of rate-limiting reaction assisted by CO2. For the Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 catalyst, the two Pt-H bonds of H-Pt-H species need to cleavage to generate an H2 molecule in the absence of CO2, and the distance between Pt and H atom in the TS structure is extended to more than 1.99 Å. In the presence of CO2, only one Pt-H bond needs to break with the generation of HCOO- intermediate, and the distance between Pt and H atom is decreased to 1.67 Å in the TS structure. Same phenomenon is observed over the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst, in the absence of CO2, the Pt-H bond and O-H bond need to break to generate H2, and the corresponding interatomic distance between H and Pt or O atom is elongated to 1.86 and 1.37 Å in the TS structure. In the presence of CO2, the optimal reaction between CO2 and H- with the generation of -COOH only needs to break one Pt-H bond, and CO2 is adsorbed over the same Pt atom that bonded to H-, shortening the Pt-H bond to 1.65 Å. The above analysis on TS structures indicates that the mechanism of H- species consumption is altered with the introduction of CO2, and the H- species reacts with CO2 accompanied by the shortening of Pt-H distance during the H transfer process, which is beneficial to stabilize the transition state configuration, thus reducing the barrier. Electronic properties calculation is performed to explore the positive effect of CO2 on the rate-limiting reaction in the ethane dehydrogenation to ethene. The Bader charge calculation is provided and it is found that the electron transfer mechanism over the two catalysts is different. The reactant species (CO2 and H- species of Pt-H+O-H) transfer electrons to the catalyst in the new H-consuming route created by CO2 over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 whereas the reactant species (CO2 and H- species of H-Pt-H) gain electrons over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. In the absence of CO2, Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 transfer charges of |0.04| and |0.13| to the H- species involved in H-Pt-H and Pt-H+O-H, respectively. Notably, the charge transferred between the reactant species (CO2 and H- species of H-Pt-H or Pt-H+O-H) and Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 or Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is increased to |0.69| or |0.95| with the participation of CO2, accompanied by the generation of new reaction routes. The charge transfer is more significant over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, which would lead to a higher activity of this catalyst for the overall H-consuming reaction. It can be concluded that the introduction of CO2 promotes charge transfer and strengthens the interaction between catalyst and reactant species (CO2 and the above H-involving species), thus reducing the energy barrier and facilitating the reaction. As shown in Fig. 9, the differential charge density profile shows that the interaction only presents between the reactant species (CO2 and H- species of H-Pt-H) and the active metals in the reaction occurred over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 (Fig. 9A), whereas in addition to this interaction, it also contains the effect from framework O of ZSM-5 on the reactant species (CO2 and H- species of Pt-H+O-H) over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 (black circle in Fig. 9B). For a deeper understanding of the interaction forms between the catalyst and reactant species (CO2 and the above H-involving species), the COHP calculation is performed, as shown in Fig. 9C and 9D. For the Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 catalyst, the catalyst stabilizes the reactant species (CO2 and H- species of H-Pt-H) through the interaction of Pt with CO2 and H- in the HCOO- generation reaction, and the corresponding integral values below Fermi level are − 2.89 (Pt-O), − 2.80 (Pt-H), and − 2.52 eV (Pt-C). For the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst, the catalyst stabilizes the reactant states (CO2 and H species of Pt-H+O-H) through the interaction of Pt with C of CO2 and H- in the COOH- generation reaction, and the corresponding integral values below Fermi level are − 3.91 (Pt-C) and − 3.50 eV (Pt-H). The COHP calculation results of the two catalysts further indicate that there are obvious chemical bond interactions between the Pt active site and reactant states (CO2 and the above H-involving species), and the stabilization effect by the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst is more significant than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5. Therefore, Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 demonstrates a more positive influence on the dehydrogenation of ethane to ethene based on the examination of H-consuming route in the presence of CO2, as shown in Fig. 4 and 5. The calculation results on structural and electronic properties well explain the observed trend in kinetic barriers. According to the computational analysis of structural and electronic properties, it can be concluded that the improved performance of CO2 on the dehydrogenation of ethane is attributed to the change of reaction mechanism induced by CO2 with the shortened distance for H- species transfer and better stabilization of reactant species by the catalyst, thus reducing the energy barrier and facilitating the reaction. The detailed electronic property calculation delineates the interaction between catalyst and reactant species, which reveals that the bimetallic active sites of Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 both have an effect on the adsorbed species, in which the Pt component plays an important role in stabilizing the structures of reactant species and transition states. In addition, the framework O of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 also has a positive influence on the reaction. 4 Conclusions This work investigates the mechanism of ethane dehydrogenation to ethene and the effect of CO2 over two types of Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts by DFT calculations. The optimal reaction routes and roles of active sites over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 are identified by comparing the energy diagrams associated with all possible pathways. Over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, the rate-limiting step is the final H2 generation with a barrier of 1.64 eV. Over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, the rate-limiting step is also the final H2 generation catalyzed by the Pt site which has a barrier of 1.50 eV, while that is the dehydrogenation of ethane to form the C2H5- species catalyzed by the Zn site with a barrier of 1.54 eV. These calculation results indicate that Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is catalytically more active than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 due to a lower barrier of the rate-limiting step. Over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, the Pt atoms are main active sites for ethane dehydrogenation, while the Zn site accepts the H specie bound to Pt via H-transfer to provide more reaction space and assist in the dehydrogenation of ethane occurred at Pt sites. In comparison, both Zn and Pt sites are catalytically active for ethane dehydrogenation over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, and the framework O of ZSM-5 also participates in the reaction process, leading to the facilitation of the reaction. In the ethane dehydrogenation reaction, H- species is generated as a precursor of the rate-limiting step (H2 generation reaction) over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 and the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. When CO2 is added as a co-reactant, it can react with the H- species to generate HCOOH over Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 or CO+H2O over the Pt site of Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5, which alters the rate-limiting step with high barrier and creates a new and facile H-consuming route along with a decreased barrier. In the new H-consuming route, CO2 shortens the distance for H- species transfer and strengthens the stability of reactant states involving CO2 and H-species, thus decreasing the barrier and facilitating the reaction. The positive effect of CO2 on the ethane dehydrogenation over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is more significant. COHP calculation results demonstrate the importance of Pt sites in stabilizing the reactant structures (CO2 and H-species) by forming chemical bond interactions over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5. In addition, the differential charge density analysis further illustrates the additional contribution of framework O site of ZSM-5 on the stability of reactant structures (CO2 and H-species) by the charge transfer over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5. As a carbon resource, CO2 also can react with the generated ethyl species from ethane dehydrogenation, which competes with the ethene production as a side reaction. Compared to Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5, Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 has a good resistance for this competitive side reaction which prefers to catalyze CO2 to react with H- species, promoting the ethene generation. Therefore, the CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of ethane can be better achieved over the Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 catalyst which becomes a promising candidate for ethene production. Future catalyst design should consider the alleviation of competitive adsorption of CO2 with ethane reactant through regulation of the interaction forms between active metals and zeolite support, the interaction forms within the active metals themselves, or importing other components that can better adsorb and activate CO2 to reduce this negative effect. coredata.dc:description: This work studies the reaction mechanism and the role of CO2 in ethane dehydrogenation to ethene over two types of Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts. The calculation results demonstrate that the Pt-Zn sites have different roles, and Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 is more active than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 due to more efficient Pt-Zn sites for dehydrogenation with the assistance of framework O of ZSM-5. CO2 reacts with H- species generated from ethane dehydrogenation and creates new and facile H-consuming routes, thus promoting the reaction. The positive effect of CO2 is more significant over Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 than Pt3Zn1/ZSM-5 owing to the largely reduced barrier of rate-limiting step. Zn6Pt1/ZSM-5 greatly suppresses the competitive side reaction of CO2 with ethyl species, thus becoming a promising catalyst for ethene generation. This work deepens the mechanistic understanding of CO2-assisted dehydrogenation of light alkanes over Pt-Zn/ZSM-5 catalysts and unravels the important role of CO2, providing a useful reference for future catalyst design.
